Državni vrh dan spomina na mrtve zaznamoval s polaganjem venca k spomeniku žrtvam vseh vojn v Ljubljani
01 Nov 2019, 16:27 by STA

Predsednik republike Borut Pahor je ob današnjem dnevu spomina na mrtve v spremstvu državne delegacije položil venec k spomeniku vsem žrtvam vojn in z vojnami povezanim žrtvam ob ljubljanskem Kongresnem trgu. Polaganje venca so pospremile salve iz garde Slovenske vojske, zvok trobil policijskega orkestra in kvartet pevcev.



Foto: Sta

LJUBLJANA > Boruta Pahorja so pri polaganju venca na osrednji spominski slovesnosti ob dnevu spomina na mrtve spremljali predsednik DZ Dejan Židan, predsednik vlade Marjan Šarec, predsednik DS Alojz Kovšca, načelnica Generalštaba Slovenske vojske generalmajorka Alenka Ermenc in generalna direktorica Policije Tatjana Bobnar.
Osrednje državno spominsko obeležje žrtvam vseh vojn, ki so prizadele slovenski narod, k spravi in edinosti ob Kongresnem trgu kliče od julija 2016, od lani pa je ceremonial polaganja venca k spomeniku sprave tudi del programa vseh uradnih obiskov visokih tujih državnikov ter osrednji kraj polaganja vencev ob 1. novembru.
Premier Šarec in predsednik DZ Židan sta se nato iz središča mesta nato preselila na Žale, kjer sta položila vence k pomniku padlim v vojni za Slovenijo 1991, Židan pa tudi k spomeniku padlim v Narodnoosvobodilnem boju, k lipi sprave in h kostnici žrtev prve svetovne vojne.
Predstavniki države so se udeležili komemoracij in položili vence ob različna obeležja in spomenike po državi in v zamejstvu, med drugimi je minister za Slovence v zamejstvu in po svetu Peter Jožef Česnik položil venec v nekdanjem taborišču Gonars.
Predsednik vlade Šarec je že dopoldan v Kamniku položil venec pri spomeniku Rudolfu Maistru.
Dopoldanske žalne slovesnosti pri grobnici na Urhu so se udeležili Židan, ljubljanski župan Zoran Janković ter poslanca SMC Jani Möderndorfer in SD Marko Koprivc. “Spoštujemo zgodovino slovenskega naroda in ohranjamo spomin na junake, ki so nas osvobodili ter pri tem žrtvovali lastna življenja,” je ob tem Židan zapisal na svojem profilu na twitterju.
V mariborski občini so dan spomina na mrtve obeležili s komemorativno slovesnostjo na osrednjem prostoru partizanskega grobišča in polaganjem venca na grobišče padlim v prvi svetovni vojni.
Evropski poslanec Milan Brglez pa je v poslanici ob današnjem dnevu poudaril, si vsak zasluži pravico do dostojnega pokopa in groba, za kar mora poskrbeti država na spoštljiv in pieteten način.
Dan spomina na mrtve, prvi november, je državni praznik in dela prost dan. Za ta dan je značilno obiskovanje grobov bližnjih, polaganje cvetja nanje in prižiganje sveč v spomin na pokojne. Praznik, ki je bil dela prost dan že v Socialistični republiki Sloveniji, ko smo ga imenovali dan mrtvih, je v samostojni Sloveniji po navedbah etnologov ohranil podobno vlogo in način obeleževanja kot v družbenopolitičnem sistemu pred letom 1991.Zaradi večjega obiska pokopališč bodo danes marsikje veljali posebni prometni režimi. Pričakovati je gnečo in prometne zastoje, zato se je na pot treba odpraviti pravočasno. Hkrati policisti, redarji in upravljavci pokopališč pozivajo k skrbi za varnost imetja.

National Day marks the day of commemoration of the dead by laying a wreath at the monument to the victims of all wars in Ljubljana
01 Nov 2019, 15:27 by STA

President of the Republic of Slovenia Borut Pahor today laid a wreath at the memorial service to all victims of the war and the war-related victims near the Congress Square in Ljubljana, accompanied by a state delegation. The laying of wreaths were accompanied by salvos from the Slovenian Army Guards, the sound of the trumpet of a police orchestra and a quartet of singers.



Photo: Sta

LJUBLJANA> Borut Pahor was accompanied by the National Assembly Speaker Dejan Zidan, Prime Minister Marjan Sarc, the President of the DS Alojz Kovsca, the Chief of the General Staff of the Slovenian Armed Forces Major General Alenka Ermenc and the Director General of the Police Tatjana Bobnar during the laying of the wreath at the central commemoration ceremony.
The central national commemoration of the victims of all wars affecting the Slovenian nation has been calling for reconciliation and unity on the Congress Square since July 2016, and since last year, the ceremonial laying of the wreath at the reconciliation monument is also part of the program of all official visits of high foreign statesmen and the central place of laying wreaths. at November 1st.
Prime Minister Šarec and the President of the Židan National Assembly then moved from the city center to Žale, where they laid wreaths to commemorate the fallen in the war for Slovenia in 1991, and Židan also to the monument to the fallen in the National Liberation War, to the linden reconciliation and to the ossuary of the victims of the First World War. .
Representatives of the country attended the commemoration and laid wreaths at various sites and monuments around the country and abroad, including Minister for Slovenes Abroad and Peter Jožef Česnik laid a wreath at the former Gonars camp.
Prime Minister Sarac laid a wreath at the Rudolf Maister monument in Kamnik this morning.
Morning mourning ceremonies at the Urh tomb were attended by Zidan, Ljubljana Mayor Zoran Jankovic and SMC deputies Jani Möderndorfer and SD Marko Koprivc. "We respect the history of the Slovenian nation and preserve the memory of the heroes who set us free and sacrificed their own lives," Židan wrote on his profile on twitter.
In the municipality of Maribor, commemoration of the dead was commemorated with a commemorative ceremony in the central area of the partisan cemetery and laying a wreath at the cemetery of those killed in World War I.
MEP Milan Brglez, however, stressed in his letter today that everyone deserves the right to a decent burial and grave, which must be done in a respectful and pietistic manner by the state.
The Day of Remembrance of the Dead, November 1st, is a national holiday and is a day off. The day is characterized by visiting the graves of loved ones, laying flowers on them and lighting candles in memory of the deceased. According to ethnologists, the holiday, which was already a day off in the Socialist Republic of Slovenia when it was called the Day of the Dead, has retained a similar role and way of commemorating it in the social-political system before 1991. special traffic regimes. Traffic jams and traffic jams are to be expected and the route must be timely. At the same time, cops, police officers and cemetery managers are calling for the safety of the property.
